prompt.p: A 35-year-old man presents to his GP complaining of tiredness and lethargy. He feels dizzy on standing from a sitting position. The GP notices a perioral lesion and examines the oral cavity (see figure). Recent haematological investigation reveals:
What is the most likely diagnosis?
Douglas et al., Macleod's Clinical Examination , 11 th edn.

modalFeedback.p: Option B (Addison's disease) is Correct. Addison's disease is characterised by mineralocorticoid deficiency causing hyponatraemia, hyperkalaemia and hypoglycaemia. Pituiatry adrenocorticotroph hormone (ACTH) increases in response to adrenal corticoid deficiency, Hyperpigmentation can be a sign of Addison's disease and is due to the increase of alpha-melanocyte-stimulating hormone which accompanies the increase in ACTH.
[Fig. reproduced from Douglas et al., Macleod's Clinical Examination , 11 th edn., 2005, with permission from Elsevier. Fig. 2.8(B) Addison's disease (buccal pigmentation)]
Option A (Acromegaly) is Incorrect. This can present with tiredness, headaches and sweats. There is no buccal or perioral pigmentation. Development of facial features occurs over years.

Option C (Conn's syndrome) is Incorrect. An adrenal adenoma would cause hypertension, hypernatraemia and hypokalaemia due to mineralocorticoid excess. It can present with muscle weakness, polydipsia and polyuria.
Option D (Cushing syndrome) is Incorrect. An excess of glucocorticoid results in weight gain, hypertension, hyperglycaemia, hypernatraemia and hypokalaemia.
Option E (Diabetes mellitus) is Incorrect. This presents with weakness, lethargy, polyuria and polydipsia or even coma. The patient would be hyperglycaemic. There is no pigmentation present.
